guide.introduction:
I was always terrified of jellyfish as a kid. The thought of a slimy translucent blob just below the water’s surface that could deliver a painful sting kept me out of the ocean most of the summer. It wasn’t until years later when I collected a small jellyfish at the beach and observed it in an aquarium that I realized how stunningly beautiful they are. As it pulsed steadily and allowed its tentacles to flutter behind it, I was completely hypnotized. Soon, I decided to design and build an aquarium that could keep jellyfish alive and well. Convert a regular aquarium into a jellyfish habitat.

Jellyfish can’t live in a regular aquarium because they get sucked into the filtration pumps and liquefied. Using my extensive experience in building aquariums as part of my research projects at Duke and the University of Delaware, I developed a tank with a special water flow to keep jellies suspended in the middle of the tank. The jellyfish aquarium design described in this article has no dead spots for water flow, eliminates strong points of suction, and creates a laminar water flow pattern that sweeps the delicate jellyfish away from the edges of the tank.

Relevant parts
  • Polycarbonate sheet, 1/32" thick
  • Salt water pump
  • PVC glue
  • PVC caps, slip, ½"
  • PVC pipe, Schedule 40, ½" diameter, 2' length
  • PVC tee fitting, slip × slip × female pipe thread, ½"
  • PVC pipe, Schedule 40, 1½" diameter, 2' length
  • PVC hose barb fittings, male pipe thread sized for ½" flexible hose
  • PVC ball valve, slip × slip, ½"
  • PVC fitting(s) to connect ½" hose barb to ½" valve to water pump
  • PVC adapter, male pipe thread × slip, 1½"
  • PVC elbow, slip × slip, 1½"
  • Plastic epoxy
  • Teflon tape
  • Threaded bulkhead fitting, 1½"
  • Flexible hose, ½" diameter, 3' length
  • Mesh screen, cut to (width of tank + 2") × (½ height of tank)
  • Plastic bio-balls, about 3gals
  • Twist ties or zip ties
  • Acrylic strips: ½" × 1" × outside width of tank; and ½" × 1" × inside width of tank
  • Salt water
  • Submersible aquarium heater
  • Aquarium tank
  • Acrylic sheets, ½" thick: 28"×23" (bottom); 28"×17" (2, sides); 22"×17" (2, ends); 22"×1" (2, braces); 23"×1" (brace)
  • Polycarbonate sheet: Polycarbonate sheet: 21 7/8"×45"×1/32"
  • Dimensional lumber, 2×4, 8' lengths
Tools
  • Acrylic cement
  • Diamond hole saw
  • Dremel with 1/8" drill bit and router
  • PVC pipe cutter
  • Ruler or straightedge
  • Tape measure

lines.text: The acrylic sheets come with a protective wax paper covering. Peel back the paper 1" from each edge you plan to glue, and use a ruler or straightedge to tear the excess (peeled) paper off.
lines.text_raw: The acrylic sheets come with a protective wax paper covering. Peel back the paper 1" from each edge you plan to glue, and use a ruler or straightedge to tear the excess (peeled) paper off.

lines.text: Use a saw and drill to build a 90º jig from the 2×4s to hold the acrylic pieces in place while the glue sets.
lines.text_raw: Use a saw and drill to build a 90º jig from the 2×4s to hold the acrylic pieces in place while the glue sets.

lines.text: Use acrylic cement at the joints to weld the tank together (refer to instructions included with the cement, and see Step 3 for placement of braces). The cement enters the cracks through capillary action.
lines.text_raw: Use acrylic cement at the joints to weld the tank together (refer to instructions included with the cement, and see Step 3 for placement of braces). The cement enters the cracks through capillary action.

lines.text: Use aquarium-grade silicone caulking to seal all the glued joints to prevent water from leaking (normal silicone caulking isn’t rated for salt water and will degrade quickly; it may also leach into the water and kill your jellyfish).
lines.text_raw: Use aquarium-grade silicone caulking to seal all the glued joints to prevent water from leaking (normal silicone caulking isn’t rated for salt water and will degrade quickly; it may also leach into the water and kill your jellyfish).

lines.text: After the joints are completely dry, peel the rest of the wax paper off the acrylic.
lines.text_raw: After the joints are completely dry, peel the rest of the wax paper off the acrylic.

lines.text: Cut the ½" PVC pipe into 2 equal pieces — these will be assembled with the tee fitting and 2 slip caps to form the spray bar.
lines.text_raw: Cut the ½" PVC pipe into 2 equal pieces — these will be assembled with the tee fitting and 2 slip caps to form the spray bar.

lines.text: Glue the 2 pieces of ½" PVC pipe on either side of the tee fitting. Glue the slip caps onto the ends using PVC glue.
lines.text_raw: Glue the 2 pieces of ½" PVC pipe on either side of the tee fitting. Glue the slip caps onto the ends using PVC glue.

lines.text: Using a Dremel or a drill press with a 1/8" bit, drill holes in the PVC pipe on the side opposite the tee fitting’s opening. The holes should be approximately ½" apart, following a straight line from one end of the spray bar to the other.
lines.text_raw: Using a Dremel or a drill press with a 1/8" bit, drill holes in the PVC pipe on the side opposite the tee fitting’s opening. The holes should be approximately ½" apart, following a straight line from one end of the spray bar to the other.

lines.text: Screw a hose barb fitting into the tee using teflon tape.
lines.text_raw: Screw a hose barb fitting into the tee using teflon tape.

lines.text: The PVC pieces should be cut so that the final length of the spray bar is a little narrower than the width of your tank. Before gluing, make sure the assembled spray bar fits inside the width of your tank.
lines.text_raw: The PVC pieces should be cut so that the final length of the spray bar is a little narrower than the width of your tank. Before gluing, make sure the assembled spray bar fits inside the width of your tank.

lines.text: Using plastic epoxy or acrylic cement, glue the long acrylic brace on top of the tank at a distance from the drain side of the tank equal to 1/3 of the tank height.
lines.text_raw: Using plastic epoxy or acrylic cement, glue the long acrylic brace on top of the tank at a distance from the drain side of the tank equal to 1/3 of the tank height.

lines.text: Cut out the corners of the screen as shown. The longer, straight sides will be glued to cross-braces and the short, beveled sides will be glued to the inside of the tank.
lines.text_raw: Cut out the corners of the screen as shown. The longer, straight sides will be glued to cross-braces and the short, beveled sides will be glued to the inside of the tank.

lines.text: Epoxy one long side of the screen to one of the shorter acrylic braces. Add more epoxy on top, and sandwich the screen between the brace and the inside of the tank, on the drain side, about 1/3 of the way down from the top. Hold it in place and allow the epoxy to cure to a strong hold.
lines.text_raw: Epoxy one long side of the screen to one of the shorter acrylic braces. Add more epoxy on top, and sandwich the screen between the brace and the inside of the tank, on the drain side, about 1/3 of the way down from the top. Hold it in place and allow the epoxy to cure to a strong hold.

lines.text: Glue the opposite side of the screen under and around the long brace on top of the tank. Gently pull the screen taut and hold it in place while the epoxy cures. Fold the short sides of the screen in and epoxy them against the inside of the tank.
lines.text_raw: Glue the opposite side of the screen under and around the long brace on top of the tank. Gently pull the screen taut and hold it in place while the epoxy cures. Fold the short sides of the screen in and epoxy them against the inside of the tank.

lines.text: Cut out a circle slightly bigger than the bulkhead fitting in the middle of the tank’s exit screen side, as far up as it can go without the fitting overlapping the top of the tank.
lines.text_raw: Cut out a circle slightly bigger than the bulkhead fitting in the middle of the tank’s exit screen side, as far up as it can go without the fitting overlapping the top of the tank.

lines.text: Install the bulkhead fitting in the hole. Using teflon tape, screw the 1½" male pipe thread (MPT) × slip adapter into the outside of the bulkhead fitting.
lines.text_raw: Install the bulkhead fitting in the hole. Using teflon tape, screw the 1½" male pipe thread (MPT) × slip adapter into the outside of the bulkhead fitting.

lines.text: Cut a 3" long piece of 1½" PVC pipe and use it to connect the 1½" male pipe thread MPT × slip adapter to the 1½" PVC elbow, pointing down.
lines.text_raw: Cut a 3" long piece of 1½" PVC pipe and use it to connect the 1½" male pipe thread MPT × slip adapter to the 1½" PVC elbow, pointing down.

lines.text: Cut a piece of 1½" PVC pipe long enough to run from the 1½" PVC elbow into the bucket beside the tank.
lines.text_raw: Cut a piece of 1½" PVC pipe long enough to run from the 1½" PVC elbow into the bucket beside the tank.

lines.text: If you’re using an acrylic tank you can make the hole with a hole saw or Dremel with a router fitting. If you’re using a glass tank you need to make the hole with a diamond hole saw.
lines.text_raw: If you’re using an acrylic tank you can make the hole with a hole saw or Dremel with a router fitting. If you’re using a glass tank you need to make the hole with a diamond hole saw.

lines.text: Using the necessary adapters, attach the ½" hose barb fitting to the ½" valve, and attach the valve to the pump.
lines.text_raw: Using the necessary adapters, attach the ½" hose barb fitting to the ½" valve, and attach the valve to the pump.

lines.text: Attach the ½" flexible hose to the hose barb fitting. Put the pump and heater at the bottom of the bucket, and fill the bucket with bio-balls or whatever pieces of plastic you’ll be using for the filter.
lines.text_raw: Attach the ½" flexible hose to the hose barb fitting. Put the pump and heater at the bottom of the bucket, and fill the bucket with bio-balls or whatever pieces of plastic you’ll be using for the filter.

lines.text: Attach the free end of the ½" flexible hose to the hose barb fitting on the spray bar.
lines.text_raw: Attach the free end of the ½" flexible hose to the hose barb fitting on the spray bar.

lines.text: Use 2 zip or twisty ties to tie the spray bar in place so the sheet of water will wash across the exit screen.
lines.text_raw: Use 2 zip or twisty ties to tie the spray bar in place so the sheet of water will wash across the exit screen.

lines.text: Epoxy the remaining acrylic brace flat inside the end of the tank opposite the drain, flush with the top.
lines.text_raw: Epoxy the remaining acrylic brace flat inside the end of the tank opposite the drain, flush with the top.

lines.text: Wedge the polycarbonate sheet into the tank so that it runs along the bottom and curves up at each end, held down by the two braces glued inside the tank. (If you built a tank 28"×23"×17" high, your polycarbonate sheet should measure 45"×21 7/8".)
lines.text_raw: Wedge the polycarbonate sheet into the tank so that it runs along the bottom and curves up at each end, held down by the two braces glued inside the tank. (If you built a tank 28"×23"×17" high, your polycarbonate sheet should measure 45"×21 7/8".)

lines.text: Fill the tank with salt water. You can get pre-mixed salt water or mix it yourself with aquarium salt, but make sure you use distilled or reverse-osmosis (RO) filtered water. Do not use unfiltered tap water.
lines.text_raw: Fill the tank with salt water. You can get pre-mixed salt water or mix it yourself with aquarium salt, but make sure you use distilled or reverse-osmosis (RO) filtered water. Do not use unfiltered tap water.

lines.text: Plug in the pump and heater, and allow the water to heat to the natural temperature of the jellyfish you’ll be adding (almost all commercially available jellies are kept at 77°F).
lines.text_raw: Plug in the pump and heater, and allow the water to heat to the natural temperature of the jellyfish you’ll be adding (almost all commercially available jellies are kept at 77°F).

lines.text: Add jellyfish. Moon jellyfish do best in these aquariums. (If you can’t collect jellyfish from the ocean, you can buy jellyfish and jellyfish food from my company: http://www.jellyfishart.com). Adjust the valve so there’s just enough water flow to keep the jellyfish from settling on the bottom. Water has a lot of momentum, so wait at least 10 minutes after adjusting the valve to observe the effect on water flow.
lines.text_raw: Add jellyfish. Moon jellyfish do best in these aquariums. (If you can’t collect jellyfish from the ocean, you can buy jellyfish and jellyfish food from my company: http://www.jellyfishart.com). Adjust the valve so there’s just enough water flow to keep the jellyfish from settling on the bottom. Water has a lot of momentum, so wait at least 10 minutes after adjusting the valve to observe the effect on water flow.

lines.text: Adjust the position of the spray bar so water washes over the exit screen without creating any air bubbles, and the jellyfish don’t get stuck to the screen. You can feed your jellyfish live brine shrimp or frozen plankton foods made specifically for jellyfish. Learn more about the care and feeding of jellyfish at http://www.jellyfishart.com.
lines.text_raw: Adjust the position of the spray bar so water washes over the exit screen without creating any air bubbles, and the jellyfish don’t get stuck to the screen. You can feed your jellyfish live brine shrimp or frozen plankton foods made specifically for jellyfish. Learn more about the care and feeding of jellyfish at http://www.jellyfishart.com.

lines.text: Change 25% of the water every 2 weeks once your tank is running. For maximum longevity with coastal jellyfish (from their natural lifespan of about 8 months up to a year or more), feed them twice a day and use a robust filtration system. Try lighting your jellies from the side or top of the tank. The light will bounce off their translucent bodies and make them glow. You can use color-changing LEDs to make the jellyfish light up with whatever colors you shine on them.
